A« BASIC LEGAL RKQUIREMEMS FOR THE LICENSEE
Every broadcasting 3tation roust have a licensee who thereby assumes certain
responsibilities before the law©
(1) All stations must be operated in accordance with the provisions
of the Commuicatlois Act of 193L and the Federal Communications Commission’s
Rules. Among other things these require that the licensee be ultimately
responsible to the Commission for the station’s program output end technical
operation. This responsibility cannot be shifted to anyone else; the
licensee therefore must be prepared to undergo any penalties assessed
{gainst him by either the FCC or the Federal Courts as a result of violations

(2) The Commission^ Rules also provide that the licensee of a non¬
commercial educational television station be prepared to 3erve the general
educational television needs of its entire area} in other words, such
licensee could not operate solely with reference to its own immediate
interests* Among other things it must make air time available to other
educational groups and agencies.
(3) Many legal rasponsibilities stemming from other sources than
the Communications Act of 193U also must be borne by station licensees.
Thus a licensee must comply with the copyright laws or be subject to civil
suits for their infringement. He also is subject to libel and slander suits
growing out of material he may have broadcast. In addition to these matters
